awd_titl_txt: Improving the Understanding of New Physics, from Particle Physics to Cosmology, at the LHC
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Peisi Huang at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

The Large Hadron Collider is a vast underground machine that scatters beams of protons against each other in order to study the fundamental constituents of matter, known as elementary particles.  Given huge amounts of data from the LHC and generations of colliders before it, we currently have a fairly robust understanding of the elementary particles and the forces between them that is encapsulated within the so-called Standard Model of particle physics.  However, there is overwhelming evidence that there is new physics beyond the Standard Model. Professor Huang's research aims to substantially extend the discovery potential for new physics at the Large Hadron Collider by using theoretical insights in both particle physics and cosmology.  As such, Professor Huang's research advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions:  the discovery and understanding of new physical laws.   This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts.  The proposed research will provide training opportunities for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students.  Professor Huang will also aim to increase participation in STEM by making a special effort to involve women, other underrepresented minorities, and first-generation college students.

More technically, in this research, three theoretical studies will be addressed to significantly enhance the discovery potential of the Large Hadron Collider.  First, to propose novel searches, theoretical implications of the current LHC data will be interpreted and developed.  Second, to enable indirect searches, this research will study the implications of precision Higgs measurements for new physics.  Third, to leverage LHC for cosmology studies, this research will establish connections between the history of the universe and LHC physics by providing theoretical motivations and calculations of important processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research substantially extends the discovery potential at the Large Hadron Collider by using theoretical insights in both particle physics and cosmology to lead to breakthroughs in physics. The Large Hadron Collider is a proton-proton collision machine studying fundamental constituents of matter, known as elementary particles. Our current understanding of elementary particles and forces between them is described by the Standard Model of particle physics. However, there is overwhelming evidence that there is new physics beyond the Standard Model. This research contributes towards the discovery and understanding of beyond Standard Model physics at the Large Hadron Collider from three directions of theoretical studies.

 In the first direction, this research interprets two key measurements from the Large Hadron Collider beauty and the Collider Detector at Fermilab. This research further investigates the theoretical implications of those results and proposes novel search directions for further experiments. In the second direction, this research investigates how to enable indirect searches for beyond standard model physics otherwise hidden at the Large Hadron Collider experiments. In particular, this research determines how beyond Standard Model physics affects the double Higgs production at the Large Hadron Collider. In addition, this research obtained systematically the effect of introducing new heavy fermions at the Large Hadron Collider.In the third direction, this research establishes connections between the history of the universe and the Large Hadron Collider physics by providing theoretical motivations and calculations. In particular, this research first studies the cosmological effects by introducing new fermions and determines the corresponding signal on both the Large Hadron Collider and gravitational wave interferometers. This research further establishes the connection between the Large Hadron Collider Physics and Primordial Black Holes, and the matter-antimatter asymmetry of the Universe, and predicts the correlated signal on collider experiments and gravitational wave interferometers.

Intellectual Merit

This research demonstrates how theoretical insights can be utilized to maximize the discovery potential of the Large Hadron Collider.  This work builds new physics models and initiates novel search directions motivated by the new models. Those new searches can be investigated over the coming years at the Large Hadron Collider, and will significantly enhance the discovery potential of the Large Hadron Collider. The indirect searches studied in this research lead to new probes of new physics in a model-independent way and are complementary to the current direct new physics searches. Finally, this work further extends the discovery potential of the Large Hadron Collider beyond the field of particle physics to the field of cosmology by establishing connections between finite-temperature physics, which is related to the history of the universe, and zero-temperature physics, which can be measured at the Large Hadron Collider. With the connections, LHC will greatly improve the understanding of cosmology, including the question of why our universe is made almost entirely of matter instead of an equal amount of matter and anti-matter created in the early universe, and primordial black holes. 

Broader Impacts

This research provides training opportunities for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Special efforts are made to increase participation in STEM by involving first-generation college students.
